discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Transcriptions and Editorials for Publicly Recorded Calls

content.content: Summary We provide written summaries of publicly recorded calls in the form of transcriptions and editorials to improve information accessibility. These allow reading as an option for anybody who isn’t able to listen in on a given call. In an effort to measure the value of this work, we are gauging community sentiment regarding whether we should continue running this program.  Cost Monthly Cost: ~$2500 - $3500 (varies) Estimated average cost per semi-transcribed summary: ~$300 Dai Estimated average cost per editorial summary: ~$150 Dai  Value We don’t have a good means by which to measure call summary utilization due to the limitations of the Maker Forum. The value provided can be theoretically measured in terms of “time saved” for stakeholders. Additionally, the summaries provide a type of historic archive of activity at the DAO.  Polls    Is this program as a whole worth it?  Yes No     0 voters        What level of call support would you like to see?  Summaries for all public calls Summaries for specified calls upon request No more summaries; they are a waste of money     0 voters      Core Units and call hosts are encouraged to participate in this poll or to comment on it: @Recognized-Delegates, @Core-Facilitators, @retro, @prose11, @thomas.flitter, @Davidutro, and @patrick_j

Some remarks:  Cost     Artem_Gordon:  Monthly Cost: ~$2500 - $3500 (varies)   1.- Does this include your cost of running the program? If it takes you 10 hours per week, that means that some 25% of your compensation should be up there. 2.- Does this include the cost of onboarding new scribes? I’m guessing new people take longer to produce summaries.  Measuring     Artem_Gordon:  We don’t have a good means by which to measure call summary utilization due to the limitations of the Maker Forum   1.- Do they need to be stored in the Maker Forum?  Accessibility     Artem_Gordon:  historic archive of activity at the DAO   Not sure how accessible they are (in terms of search, topics, groups, tags, etc.). Also, I don’t even know if some solution exists to manage this better (I suspect @twblack88 knows the perfect tool). Maybe the forum is not the place to store this kind of information? Hope that helps.

I have to admit, once I host a call and post the video, I don’t really engage with the transcript. I’m not really in a position to comment on the value of this service for our ‘consumers’. I can say, I have never gotten any feedback (positive or negative) on a call’s transcript from the community on one of my calls. Leadership minded - I’d want to look at data to make this call. Some things come to mind:  Post (comment) read time Post (comment) views Topic read time & views pre/post transcript publishing Unique accounts engaging with Post (comment) How the transcript is indexed on Google, if at all 5a) If Indexed, inbound traffic generated by lead sources      Artem_Gordon:  We don’t have a good means by which to measure call summary utilization due to the limitations of the Maker Forum.   I’m far from a forum expert, would anyone with more knowledge than me be able to comment on if we can implement these? screen-track.js.es6 Forum Community Metics

Hey, Juan, thanks for your input      juan:  1.- Does this include your cost of running the program?   There is almost no cost to running the program. I am involved at a minimum level, which includes managing the team and a final review before posting the transcription on the Forum. Most of this managing is done through a tracker sheet and schedule.     juan:  2.- Does this include the cost of onboarding new scribes?   There is a small cost for onboarding new scribes. I have a document containing prerecorded onboarding videos and quizzes as a mandatory requirement to be onboarded. It’s about 3-4 hours long, and new hires get paid 100 Dai to complete it. However, there has only been one new hire during Q2.     juan:  Do they need to be stored in the Maker Forum?   That’s a good question. I would like to reduce the number of clicks a person would have to go through to reach a transcription, which is why they are posted directly under the respective ‘public-call’ thread. But one alternative is to upload the transcription as a web PDF and then link that to the YouTube video description.     juan:  Not sure how accessible they are (in terms of search, topics, groups, tags, etc.).   I agree. The advanced search filter option is helpful but does not always bring up the most relevant thread (from my own experience). I have thought about whether this happens to others if trying to look up something mentioned in a public call. Overall, the forum may not be the ideal place for transcriptions, but the question we bring forward is whether transcriptions are being used at all.

This program is very useful for the DAO in general, public written records of the calls are necessary, as it follows the line of transparency that every DAO should have in itself. It also allows to have a more correct control if any Core Unit, facilitator or any person who participates in them is aware of the words that were said, what was promised to do or what was said.

Hey, Retro, thanks for the feedback!     Retro:  I have never gotten any feedback (positive or negative) on a call’s transcript from the community   I’m in a very similar boat, which is one of the reasons that we created this poll. The poll results will provide us with feedback.     Retro:   Post (comment) read time Post (comment) views Topic read time & views pre/post transcript publishing Unique accounts engaging with Post (comment) How the transcript is indexed on Google, if at all 5a) If Indexed, inbound traffic generated by lead sources    I’ve already attempted to get these metrics with the help of TechOps and the Discourse team. The challenge is that most Discourse metrics are presented for the entire community (do not provide our needed metrics for individual threads/replies). I haven’t thought about indexing or SEO (#5), but that may be one potential method for obtaining metrics if a Google Analytics API is integrated and records individual threads and replies; Not sure. Also, not being an admin for the forum hinders my ability to experiment with building or obtaining metrics.     Retro:  screen-track.js.es6 Forum Community Metics   Thanks

Hey!      Saludiego_201:  This program is very useful for the DAO in general, public written records of the calls are necessary, as it follows the line of transparency that every DAO should have in itself.   This is one of the values that uphold the transcription program. But we are at a point where there is information complexity across the forum as well as a growing difficulty in filtering an advanced search for specific topics or words.     Saludiego_201:  It also allows to have a more correct control if any Core Unit, facilitator or any person who participates in them is aware of the words that were said, what was promised to do or what was said.   Maybe, but these transcriptions are probably the least of worries for facilitators and speakers. Overall, even if both reasons are true, how can we measure them as value metrics? And is that value greater than the cost for the program?

juan:  (I suspect @twblack88 knows the perfect tool).   Otter.ai would be it, yet it struggles greatly with pauses and acronyms. Guessing here, but I would suspect whatever efficiency it gains we have to clean up editing instead.     Artem_Gordon:  filtering an advanced search for specific topics or words.   :shaking-fists-at-sky: for advanced search. However, googling with site:forum.makerdao.com does work better than Discourse search.

What about stopping for a month, and use the $2500 budget on a bounty on some web3 platform to get an MVP built?  These metrics will be valuable on more than just transcripts. Redirect transactional, questionable value to potential investments. Worst case, if the bounty doesnt work out, we have the same reault as a transcript that isnt read.

It does seem like a nice idea that isn’t actually getting used. As long as we are storing the audio recordings, we can always transcribe later. Especially as automated captioning continues to improve, this could reasonably be done with software as needed.     Saludiego_201:  This program is very useful for the DAO in general,   Can you be more specific regarding who its useful for? If nobody is actually reading the transcripts, then it objectively isn’t useful.

twblack88:  Otter.ai would be it, yet it struggles greatly with pauses and acronyms. Guessing here, but I would suspect whatever efficiency it gains we have to clean up editing instead.   Yep, we already use Otter.ai as part of the transcription process. Some scribes claim it helps and others say it makes it slightly more difficult. But I can confirm that it requires a lot of editing. But implementing Otter did improve the transcription accuracy by helping to identify certain words and speaker’s names.

Retro:  What about stopping for a month, and use the $2500 budget on a bounty on some web3 platform to get an MVP built? These metrics will be valuable on more than just transcripts. Redirect transactional, questionable value to potential investments. Worst case, if the bounty doesnt work out, we have the same reault as a transcript that isnt read.   Hmm, thanks for the idea. Do you know anybody else who is also interested in gathering similar metrics on the Forum?

CodeKnight:  It does seem like a nice idea that isn’t actually getting used. As long as we are storing the audio recordings, we can always transcribe later. Especially as automated captioning continues to improve, this could reasonably be done with software as needed   I agree. Transcription work gets easier and more automated over time. In the future, we may just need a single person to run a software, fix up some format and etc, and then have it ready in less than half the time it takes now. Additionally, once we migrate from Discourse to something of a more web3 native social community platform, could even change the game on how we add information to threads, posts, and videos.

Artem_Gordon:  There is almost no cost to running the program. I am involved at a minimum level, which includes managing the team and a final review before posting the transcription on the Forum. Most of this managing is done through a tracker sheet and schedule.   almost no cost might be an overstatement. @Artem_Gordon how many hours per month on average do you spend working the program?

@Davidutro I’ll run a quick mental math calculation: Takes about 20-30 minutes of work per call (broken up into increments of 5-10 minutes over the course of several days). There are on avg. 2 semi-transcription calls per week, totaling 40-60 minutes per week. That’s 160-240 minutes (2.5-3 hours) per month = $100-120 of operational time spent annually, that’s $1,200-1,440.

Two points here. First while I have not used the transcriptions or editorials I can say for a fact that if you don’t have them it is impossible to search for anything.   Transcriptions make it possible to search for keywords and to isolate discussions - REALLY, really important if you think what Maker discussed in the past is important for discussions on same topic now.   Personally I think the DAO is caring less about what was discussed a year ago on any topic since many new posters frequently try to engage on the same topics that have been discussed in the past without doing a search.  I can also say that using the search doesn’t often yield what I know I am looking for but I have not spent a lot of time on finding out why. There also is no sense of gathering DAO discussions on topics in transcriptions to create a discussion topic library (I mean we don’t have money and time I am sure). Lastly.  This subject is a perfect job for someone visually disabled like my wife as she used to do book conversions to braille paid for by the page at not so great a rate btw (she maybe earned $8-10/hr a decade ago).  Not sure she would do it but visually disabled people desperately need incomes - why not post a job with reasonable hourly or pay/page specifically for someone who is visually disabled to work on.? I look at monthly cost as listed at 2.5-3K, not sure this would be a full or 1/2 time job for someone of if the DAO is just looking to cut costs but the DAO literally could post a part time job for transcription/editing for 30-36K/yr and I can have my wife run it by the disabled community to see if there are any takers.   Now if you want to do it on contract (i.e. by transcription) you can try that as well.  idk Just a few things to think about. I talked with my wife and one thing she was talking about was how Maker websites didn’t conform to accessibility standards (like they were not accessible), which is quite common btw.

MakerMan:  First while I have not used the transcriptions or editorials I can say for a fact that if you don’t have them it is impossible to search for anything.   Do we need call discussions to be searchable though? A lot of the conversation happens off calls. Between forum and discord, there’s a lot of searching one could do. Are call conversations special in some way that they need to be searchable? So far I haven’t encountered anyone that actually needs this level of accessibility.     MakerMan:  Lastly. This subject is a perfect job for someone visually disabled like my wife as she used to do book conversions to braille…why not post a job with reasonable hourly or pay/page specifically for someone who is visually disabled to work on.?   Mainly because we are trying to run lean, and this seems like a nice-to-have that won’t create very much impact. We’re not investing in foreign language translations for the same reason. There are scaling issues with making maker accessible to everyone. It’s not realistic without a much more significant allocation of resources so I’m not going to touch this kind of expansion.     MakerMan:  I talked with my wife and one thing she was talking about was how Maker websites didn’t conform to accessibility standards (like they were not accessible), which is quite common btw.   Yea, this is a job for whoever eventually owns the website and does a redesign. We’ll get there sooner or later

Davidutro:  Do we need call discussions to be searchable though?   Honestly seems like all the ‘discussions’ just fall through cracks and are left in the subjective memory of people.   I have never done a search but every time I see information presented in video I am like - well where in the hell was that little gem in the 1-2hr video recording. So I agree with your comment in terms of whether users have a need.  I don’t think so.  If a recording is transparency well we could just archive a shit ton of videos and have some little gems well buried after the 5000th hour of recordings that would come up instantly in searches.     Davidutro:  Mainly because we are trying to run lean, and this seems like a nice-to-have that won’t create very much impact. We’re not investing in foreign language translations for the same reason. There are scaling issues with making maker accessible to everyone. It’s not realistic without a much more significant allocation of resources so I’m not going to touch this kind of expansion.   Agree…     Davidutro:  Yea, this is a job for whoever eventually owns the website and does a redesign. We’ll get there sooner or later    And agree again.

In my opinion it is going to be very useful for DAO. Having a written record of calls makes it easy to find the exact point of the conversation someone need to refer back to. You can use the search bar to search by keywords.

This is true in theory, but in practice, I don’t have evidence that people actually do this.    Have you ever looked up a conversation from a call using the summaries?  Yes No     0 voters     Maybe some people can weigh in. @Recognized-Delegates @Core-Facilitators
Davidutro:  Have you ever looked up a conversation from a call using the summaries?   The summaries have surfaced calls for me when I’ve searched for specific terms.
@ChrisBlec That’s great to know. I wasn’t sure how effective the search function was to other users in regards to surfacing a relevant transcription. Thanks

Voted Yes for the program but added a qualifier (upon request). The calls get recorded. Automated captioning gets better every month. Let’s keep the recordings. Transcribe when requested (any participant can request ahead of call). Keep a forum post open for transcription requests. Iterate towards a threshold when actual transcription happens. My two cents. I think every chat app is dedicating massive resources to make voice messages searchable, so I’m pretty confident we’ll have searchable audio recordings within reasonable time.
